profileText: A Senator from Connecticut; born James O'Brien McMahon in Norwalk, Fairfield County, Conn., October 6, 1903; attended the public schools; graduated from Fordham University, New York City, in 1924 and from the law school of Yale University, New Haven, Conn., in 1927; admitted to the bar the same year, changed his name to Brien McMahon, and commenced practice in Norwalk, Conn.; city judge of Norwalk, Conn., in 1933, but resigned to become special assistant to the Attorney General of the United States 1933-1935; Assistant Attorney General of the United States in charge of the Department of Justice Criminal Division 1935-1939; resumed the practice of his profession in Washington, D.C., and Norwalk, Conn.; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1944; reelected in 1950 and served from January 3, 1945, until his death in Washington, D.C., July 28, 1952; co-chairman, Joint Committee on Atomic Energy (Eighty-first and Eighty-second Congresses); interment in St. Mary's Cemetery, Norwalk, Conn.

researchRecord.name: Correspondence in Frank Murphy papers, 1908-1949; and Blair Moody papers, 1928-1954. Finding aid.

1943-1952. 11 containers. General correspondence, memoranda, speeches, statements, press releases, articles, and broadcast recording (September 1948) by Charles Parmer entitled "The Senator of the Year, Brien McMahon.'' Finding aid.
Correspondence in Clinton Presba Anderson papers, 1938-1972. Finding aid.
In Harold Phelps Stokes papers, 1908-1969; and Charles-Edward Amory Winslow papers, 1874-1977 (bulk 1915-1945).
Discussed in Homer S. Cummings diaries, 1919-1959, on 3 microfilm reels of originals at University of Virginia Library.

1930-1953. 25.5 linear feet. Correspondence, manuscripts, speeches, phonograph records, photographs, and related items chiefly regarding service as assistant attorney general. Topics include the Harlan County trial, Democratic politics in the 1930s and 1940s, and Senate campaigns. A small amount of material relates to his Senate service. The bulk of his senatorial papers are at the Library of Congress. Finding aid.
